description: From Middle English culver, from Old English culufre, culfre, culfer, possibly borrowed from Vulgar Latin *columbra, from Latin columbula (“little pigeon”), from Latin columba (“pigeon, dove”).

entries.meaning: (now UK, south and east dialect or poetic) A dove or pigeon, now specifically of the species Columba palumbus.
examples: The palsie plagues my pulseswhen I prigg yoͬ: piggs or pullenyour culuers take, or matchles makeyour Chanticleare or sullen

entries.meaning: A culverin, a kind of handgun or cannon.
